description.narrative: This project is about the involvement of five different Muslim communities in the Rijnmond area of Rotterdam in the Netherlands into peace processes in their countries of origin. These are the migrant communities from Somalia , Afghanistan , Pakistan , Bosnia andMorocco . In the latter, SPIOR focuses on Syria , given the current debates in this community . SPIOR itself is also aware that Bosnia is not a priority country for Oxfam Novib , but has some good examples in the land of peace initiatives from a gender perspective , which are also relevant for the other four communities . All these communities are well represented in the Rotterdam area with active ( religious ) self-help organizations . In consultation with the communities and with Oxfam Novib, SPIOR wants to invite initiatives from the countries of origin ( and the Moroccan community in Syria ) that a working according to a gender perspective, whichmake a valuable contribution to peace and security . These partners will be invited for one week to the communities in Rotterdam. During this week they will get acquainted with specific elements of the migrant communities in Rotterdam , hold discussions with relevant key people and provide interviews and workshops with the relevant communities. The common topic will be Islam and gender . It will be somewhat dependent on the communities , but the commitment is to conduct workshop for women who are active in the organization , for the young people and for the board of the organization. Enclosed in each case with a meeting with representatives from thesethree sectors , in particular in order to give to the future relations between the host organization and its interpretation and thecommunity in Rotterdam. The guest week ends with a joint meeting of the various groups within the community , in which the further embedding of the Dutch organization on the agenda . The idea is to set up a commission. Implementation depends on the capabilities and traditions in the respective communities. This committee will maintain future relations with the partner on the theme . The purpose of the guest week is twofold : firstly, to raise awareness on the gender initiatives, peace and security in their countries of origin and Syria. Secondly to create solidarity on these initiatives in the countries of origin, and to translate into practical stepsthat communities in the Netherlands can take it forward The committees s in the five communities are then brought into contact witheach other . Besides maintaining contacts with the countries of origin, mutual knowledge sharing in the Netherlands is an important goal . This exchange should lead to a common toolkit of instruments that migrant communities can contribute to peace and security . The toolkit will be based on the practical work in the project , with particular attention to the institutional embedding in Muslim communities. The toolkit will be presented at a final meeting in which the five communities share their experiences and communicate to other communities . Also during this meeting agreement will be reached on further future cooperation .

participating-org.narrative:
SPIOR stands for Foundation Platform Islamic Organizations Rijnmond and was founded in 1988 on the initiative of 16 mosques in Rotterdam with the aim to represent their view on housing issues for mosques. SPIOR is thus from its inception always an important interlocutor for the local government. In the past 25 years SPIOR became the umbrella organization of 66 member organizations currently in the Rotterdam - Rijnmond region. This includes most of the mosques , but about two-thirds of the organizations are socio-cultural organizations of general nature. Usually not organized according to cultural background, SPIOR includes affiliated organizations of Turkish, Moroccan, Pakistani, Surinamese, Indonesian, Bosnian, Somali, Afghan, Algerian, Tunisian and Palestinian backgrounds. SPIORthus has an extensive network and, more importantly, has the confidence of large groups of 'New people from Rotterdam and Rijnmond'. In all their heterogeneity, SPIOR has two main connection points: Islamic identity and the shared objectives of promoting social participation, in many areas. In its work SPIOR is primarily inspired by its identity, while essentially pursuing objectives of social interest as a civil society organization.
The objective of SPIOR is to promote participation of Muslims in Dutch society. For this purpose, a variety of activities are proposed. The intermediary function SPIOR held from the beginning, has kept its relevance while its scope has expanded to not only housing but also education, employment, participation, empowerment, integration, security and other themes. SPIOR plays a bridging role between the grassroots on the one hand, both for individual and collective levels, and (especially local) government and other social institutions on the other. In this role SPIOR also has a signaling function.
On the basis of needs and requirements detected within both the grassroots and in society in general various projects and activities were developed over the years. As examples may be mentioned here homework guidance on Islamic education for public schools, tackling forced marriage issues, prevention around ' lover boys', training spiritual leaders, social isolation approach women, activities in the field of integration, social dialogue and improving the educational climate in mosques. Some projects have been privatized over the years. Not infrequently SPIOR has played a pioneering role putting sensitive topics on the agenda of member organizations within the constituency. Also, SPIOR is increasingly approached by various sectors of society for information and advice on a range of issues at the intersection of Islam, Muslims and Dutch society .
Overlooking the activities, it can be observed that SPIOR actually has two pillars: a support and intermediate structure between supporters and surrounding community on the one hand, and a center of expertise and development on the other. These are indeed closely associated with each other. SPIOR has in fact two different groups of "customers" to cater towards: "internal customers" (i.e. supporters or affiliated organizations) and "external customers" (government and social institutions). These groups have different and sometimes conflicting expectations of SPIOR , which puts SPIOR sometimes in a difficult position. At the same time , it is precisely this position that determines the value of the organization.
